  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Good afternoon. This is Russ Mitchell filling in for
  Katie.
 
A roaring blaze swept through a South Carolina furniture warehouse,
  sucking in the building’s roof and trapping nine firefighters who died
  in the blaze. The Charleston
  mayor called the disaster “difficult to fathom.” Truly, the scope
  of the roaring fire was immense – one bystander said it looked like a
  30-foot tornado of flames. Kelly Cobiella will have the dramatic story and
  our John Blackstone will show you how firefighters train to fight these fires.
 
Lara Logan will report on the massive truck bomb
  exploded near a Baghdad
  mosque, killing at least 75 people and injuring 130 others. The blast
  occurred just a week after the attack on the Shiite shrine in Samarra that destroyed
  two landmark minarets. This week, roughly 10,000 U.S.
  and Iraqi forces launched an offensive north of Baghdad in Baquba, aimed at clearing
  insurgents out of safe havens in the Diyala province. Lara will also have an
  update on her riveting report from last night on the Baghdad
  orphans saved by U.S.
  troops.
 
Mark Phillips will report that global warming might
  affect our future, but could also affect some of the most important markers
  of our past – landmarks that have survived for centuries. The message:
  see them now because they might not be around for much longer.
 
But getting to those landmarks is proving to be a
  struggle for some Americans. Nancy Cordes will report on the widespread rage
  over U.S.
  passport delays.
 
And finally, Byron Pitts will have the story of an
  inner-city program that’s giving underprivileged kids wings –
  literally.
 
Thanks and please join us tonight.
